Title: Early dryness led to recommendation to defend Texas properties against wildfires
Description: Much of Texas was three to four weeks ahead of typical summer drying, leading to increased fire activity and the potential for a severe wildfire season.  Residents were urged by the Texas A&M Forest Service to defend their property against fire by cleaning up dry and dead vegetative debris.EastTexasRadio.Com (Mount Pleasant, Texas), June 17, 2020

Title: Pumpkin production lower in Texas
Description: Pumpkin growers in Texas anticipated a below-average harvest this year as early rains in May and June transitioned to extreme heat and drought during the summer.  A Floyd County grower said his yields were 30 percent to 40 percent below average partially due to heat damaging first fruit sets.  He also noted that he was getting orders from all across the nation from places he does not normally supply, such as the northern U.S., California and the East Coast.The Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Oct. 8, 2019

Title: Fewer monarchs migrating north through Texas
Description: Fifty percent fewer monarch butterflies were migrating north through Texas during the 2020 spring after overwintering in Mexico.  Fall drought in Texas and northeastern New Mexico was thought to play a role in the reduced numbers. The Rivard Report (San Antonio, Texas), March 21, 2020

Title: Cattle prices decline in Texas
Description: Cattle prices were down in Texas as the state beef herd hit an eight-year high of 4.65 million and drought caused producers to cull cattle earlier and deeper than usual, among other factors.The Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Sept. 25, 2019

Title: Texas 2018 drought prompting cattle sales, due to hay shortage
Description: A hay shortage in Central Texas, along with rising hay prices, has caused some ranchers to sell cattle.  More cattle have been taken to auction since the beginning of December, according to the West Auction Managing Partner Adele Uptmore.  This trend was occurring statewide, stated Tracy Tomascik, associate director of the Commodity and Regulatory Activities with the Texas Farm Bureau.  He noted that, “Hay is in short supply and as a result of that, they are starting to liquidate and sell less productive cattle."The hay shortage stemmed from drought during Texas’ 2018 growing season, which reduced hay production. Title: Drought increased abandonment of Texas cotton
Description: The abandonment rate for the Texas Plains cotton crop will be around 40 to 50 percent, including dryland and irrigated cotton.  In 2011, a disastrous year of drought, the abandonment rate was 66 percent. Title: Hay prices rising, herds being sold in Texas
Description: Hay production southeast of Austin was about half of normal, due to heat and drought.  Poor production and low hay stocks meant that hay prices were climbing to $55 for large round bales in Central Texas in early August, pushing prices up about 22 percent compared to August 2017.  Prices were anticipated to keep climbing with the growing season ending in a few weeks.  Texas A&M University’s AgriLife Extension Service has heard of hay bales selling for as much as $125 west of Austin.    Around the state, some ranchers were selling entire herds at auction as the hay shortage portended a tough winter.  Beef cows were averaging $55.75 per 100 pounds in early August, down about 25 percent from a year ago. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 10, 2018

Title: Texas beef producers ought to be prepared in case drought persists
Description: Texas beef producers ought to plan to downsize their herds if drought continued, according to Dr. Jason Banta, AgriLife Extension beef cattle specialist.  The shortage of forage and hay will be problematic, meaning that producers might save money by whittling the herd down.  Producers must be careful not to overgraze pastures.  Cool temperatures were also part of the problem.  Winter lasted longer than usual, with a cool spring making the hay crop smaller than normal.  The second cutting was similarly below normal in quantity and quality, due to drought.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), July 8, 2018

Title: Drought affecting crops and livestock in parts of Texas
Description: Texas A&M extension agents report that in central Texas, pastures and crops are showing signs of drought stress. Some producers have begun feeding hay and protein. Most corn is being chopped for silage. In the Rolling Plains, cotton fields have dried out, and recently emerged cotton plants are stressed. Hay fields are producing less than usual. In the eastern part of the state, crop growth has slowed throughout the area. In the south plains, at least half of the dryland cotton acres did not come up, and farmers are making replant decisions about whether to plant cotton, fallow, or sorghum. In the panhandle, weeds are a problem throughout the district, and pastures and rangelands are in fair to poor condition. In the north, pastures are showing drought stress, and hay yields are about half of last year’s yield. In west central Texas, dryland grain sorghum and cotton are affected. In southwest Texas, water availability is a problem and supplemental feeding is continuing for livestock and wildlife. In southern Texas, stock tank water levels have declined in dry areas, and producers with livestock on native rangeland and pastures report supplemental feeding activity. Some producers are selling off livestock to relieve grazing pressure on native rangeland and pastures.Bryan-College Station Eagle (TX), July 3, 2018

Title: Fire activity in Texas
Description: Texas appeared to be on track to see the most wildfires since 2011, according to Texas A&M Forest Service records.  Through Aug. 9, there were 893 wildfires in the state.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 12, 2018Since the start of 2018, Texas has endured more than 870 wildfires that charred nearly 370,000 acres as drought increased fire activity in the state.  The public was asked to be cautious to avoid inadvertently sparking a fire.WBAP-AM 820 Arlington (Texas), Aug. 6, 2018

Title: More than 200 wildfires in Texas, plenty of fuel
Description: Two hundred twenty-two fires burned in Texas during the past week, consuming 30,585 acres, according to the Texas A&M Forest Service.   Spring rains in Texas promoted the growth of grasses that have become “fine fuels” with the dryness of summer months and have increased the fire danger.  Fewer cattle to graze down grasses because producers have not yet rebuilt their herds after drought also lent to the increased fuel for fires.Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Aug. 19, 2015

Title: Texas senior water rights holders not required to sacrifice during droughts
Description: In a monumental victory for senior water rights holders in Texas, the state cannot take water from senior water rights holders and give it to cities or power generators during drought, even if the water is needed for public health, safety and welfare.  Junior water rights holders, however, are not protected from such curtailments.  The 13th Court of Appeals upheld a lower court’s ruling on the matter.The Texas Tribune (Austin), April 2, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Brisket prices rising in Texas
Description: Years of rising beef prices have restaurant owners adjusting menu prices to cover the increase.  At Bert’s Bar-B-Q in Austin, the cost of brisket rose from $12 to $13 a pound to $17.  The owner expects beef prices to continue going up.TWC News - Austin TX, Feb. 23, 2015

Title: Times still tough for Texas ranchers
Description: Years long drought continued to hurt Texas ranchers who have looked at inventive ways to supplement their income.  Some have opened up their pastures to hunting and others have sold water to oil companies and desert plants and mistletoe to nurseries.  Sometimes ranchers take a full-time job to bring in a little extra money.Salina Journal & Salina.com (Kan.), Dec. 20, 2014

Title: Mineral Wells, Texas, scores of other communities within 3 months of running out of water
Description: The Palo Pinto Municipal Water District No. 1 plans to construct a $6 million reverse osmosis plant and secure water rights for the next three years from a rights holder on the Brazos River.  Lake Palo Pinto, owned by the PPMWD, is the main water source for Mineral Wells and held just 10 percent of capacity.  The lake is expected to be dry in the spring of 2015 without additional inflows.  A couple of nearby towns in Palo Pinto County, Gordon and Mingus, may be out of water by mid-February, and are working with officials in Strawn to connect to well water in rural areas to the south.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Dec. 7, 2014Mineral Wells' only water supply, Lake Palo Pinto, is at 10 percent of capacity.  Town officials are scrambling to find an alternate water source.  Mineral Wells is one of fifty-eight cities in Texas that also have an estimated 180 days’ worth of water left.WFAA-TV ABC 8 Dallas - Fort Worth (Texas), Dec. 2, 2014

Title: Water supplies low in Northwest Texas
Description: Nearly four years of drought have taken a harsh toll on Northwest Texas water supplies.  Residents of Rule in Haskell County are asked to use no more than 5,000 gallons of water per month.  Wichita Falls remained in a Stage 5 drought catastrophe.  Officials in Mineral Wells banned outdoor watering in September.  In Texas, 792 water systems had mandatory water restrictions in effect, including 322 that depend on surface water, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 27, 2014

Title: More than 30 small Texas water suppliers could be out of drinking water within 45 to 90 days
Description: More than 30 small Texas water suppliers could be out of drinking water within 45 to 90 days, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality, which assures the public that water will be brought in if faucets go dry.  There are 11 water suppliers, providing water to about 8,600 businesses and residential connections that have less than 45 days’ worth of water.  Twenty-one other suppliers have less than 90 days’ worth left.Voluntary water restrictions were in effect in 387 water systems, while mandatory water restrictions governed water use in 778 water systems.Galveston County Daily News (Texas), May 21, 2014

Title: Historically high beef prices bringing an increase in cattle rustling in Texas
Description: Historically high beef prices are bringing an increase in cattle rustling in Texas, forcing ranchers to invest in new security technology to keep a close eye on the cattle.KXXM-FM (San Antonio, Texas), May 2, 2014

Title: Roughly 25 percent of Texas water systems have voluntary or mandatory water restrictions
Description: In Texas, 1,143 of the state’s 4,642 water suppliers had imposed voluntary or mandatory water restrictions as of April 10 to extend water supplies as the state endures years of drought.  An estimated 31 public water systems have fewer than 90 days’ worth of water left, while seven systems may have less than 45 days’ worth of water remaining.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 13, 2014

Title: Texans encouraged to conserve water
Description: Texas Agriculture Commissioner Todd Staples encouraged Dallas residents to conserve water when he spoke to the Dallas Regional Chamber of Commerce.  The mayor of Frisco and the executive director of the North Texas Municipal Water District also urged people to improve their water habits and avoid wasting water as the state endures drought.  About 25 percent of Texas’ water supply entities have voluntary or mandatory water restrictions, said the state Agriculture Commissioner.  Reservoirs in the state were at 65 percent of capacity.Dallas Morning News, April 7, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: More wildflowers are blooming in Texas this year
Description: More wildflowers are blooming in Texas this year as past years of drought have killed some grass, allowing wildflowers to grow and dominate those areas, said the director of the research and landscape design program at Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center in Austin.Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 7, 2014

Title: Texas considering sea water desalination
Description: Texas Rep. Todd Hunter (R-Corpus Christi) was appointed to lead a new committee to assess whether the state should invest in water desalination as drought persists in the state.  Desalinating sea water is expensive, costing $3 to $6 per thousand gallons, according to the Texas desalination association.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 2, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Persistent drought in Texas has reduced the state’s reservoirs to puddles as water supplies never recovered from intense drought in 2011
Description: Persistent drought in Texas has reduced the state’s reservoirs to puddles as water supplies never recovered from intense drought in 2011.  State officials are prioritizing use of the remaining water, seeking new water sources and hastily constructing needed infrastructure before the next drought arrives.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 13, 2014

Title: Some Texas farmers switched to growing sorghum in 2014, due to drought and good grain prices
Description: Some Texas farmers switched to growing sorghum in 2014, due to drought and good grain prices, according to a news release from Texas A&M University.  Unfortunately, a sugarcane aphid is devastating grain sorghum crops in the state.Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Feb. 12, 2014

Title: Fewer monarch butterflies passing through Texas this fall
Description: Two years of drought and habitat destruction in the Midwest have drastically limited the number of butterflies returning to Mexico to overwinter this year.  A master naturalist and entomology specialist in Victoria, Texas said that of the 300 million monarch butterflies that left Mexico this spring, just 60 million butterflies, or 20 percent of the original butterflies’ progeny, will return to Mexico in the fall.A Texas A&M butterfly expert noted that the number of monarchs leaving Mexico last spring was low, contributing to the small number of butterflies this year.  He heard that there were so few monarchs in Canada that an annual monarch count was cancelled this fall.  Victoria Advocate (Texas), Nov. 11, 2013

Title: New Texas drought website
Description: The Texas Water Development Board rolled out a new drought website to provide water information, including updated resources, links, data and the analysis of drought conditions.  The ongoing stretch of drought began in 2011.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Oct. 24, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Ongoing drought in Texas has kept water supplies low and rangeland and pastures in poor shape, preventing ranchers from restocking
Description: Ongoing drought in Texas has kept water supplies low and rangeland and pastures in poor shape, preventing ranchers from restocking.  In January, ranchers expressed intentions to increase the number of female cattle on their ranches, but the dry summer has changed their minds.An agricultural economist at Texas A&M, said, “The drought is going to get some producers to sell those calves earlier to prevent further damage to pastures.  This dry pattern limits what cattle producers can do relative to what they planned to do.”  Washington Post (D.C.), Sept. 10, 2013

Title: Texans urged to share drought pictures on social media platforms
Description: The Texas Department of Agriculture, Texas Water Development Board and Texas Parks and Wildlife Department invite the public to post their personal drought photos on social media sites, such as Twitter and Flickr, using hashtag #txdrought, and Instagram at texasdrought, through Sept. 30.  “Photos should illustrate how the drought is affecting daily life — whether it is dry creek beds, withered crops, native plants flourishing in the dry climate or the innovative water conservation measures Texans are using to combat drought,” said the agencies in a statement.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Aug. 13, 2013

Title: Much of Texas enduring swarms of grasshoppers
Description: Much of Texas was enduring swarms of grasshoppers, which often follow a summer of drought, particularly when a dry spring follows, according to an agricultural agent from Collin County.  The dry weather slows the growth of a fungus that can kill the young grasshoppers.  Dallas Morning News (Texas), July 28, 2013

Title: Water supplies short in Texas
Description: At least a dozen water districts in Texas are within 45 days of running out of water, while another dozen have about 90 days’ worth of water left.  The 109 Texas lakes that provide drinking water were at their lowest average storage for this time of year at 64 percent.  Rivers and lakes are reaching their lowest levels for this time of year since 1990 after record drought in 2011 dramatically reduced water supplies.  Roughly 22 percent of the 4,660 public water suppliers in Texas have voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in effect.  GO San Angelo/San Angelo Standard Times (Texas), July 24, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Dry conditions in Texas limited or prevented Rio Grande turkeys from reproducing
Description: Dry conditions in Texas limited or prevented Rio Grande turkeys from mating, breeding and nesting, which is usually at its height in March and April.  Hens’ physical condition was too poor for successful reproduction, and there was not enough nesting cover, due to inadequate rainfall.  In late May through the start of June, rain fell and improved range and habitat conditions.  Some of the turkeys made a successful, albeit late, nesting effort.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), July 11, 2013

Title: New public service announcement to encourage continued water conservation in Texas
Description: The Texas Parks and Wildlife Department and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality urged the public to continue conserving water in a public service announcement featuring country music singer Kevin Fowler.  He sings “Take Care of Texas” on a riverbank.  The PSA encourages the public to enjoy outdoor recreation and to take care of the environment.  Lubbock Avalanche-Journal (Texas), June 4, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Emergency grazing on CRP acres authorized in 192 Texas counties
Description: One hundred ninety-two Texas counties are eligible for emergency grazing on Conservation Reserve Program land for the 2013 fiscal year,  effective June 2 through the next 90 days.  Only lands that were not hayed or grazed in 2011, 2012 or the fall or winter of FY 2013 may be approved for use.  The Farm Service Agency's fiscal year begins on Oct. 1.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), June 7, 2013

Title: Texas water supplies remain depleted after years of drought
Description: There were 1,011 communities in Texas with water restrictions, stated L’Oreal Stepney, the deputy director for water at the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.  He also reported that 19 water systems have less than 180 days’ worth of water, three systems have less than 45 days’ worth and one system relies on trucked-in water to meet basic needs.  The state climatologist warned the House and Senate Natural Resources Committees that the state may be headed into its second worst drought as rainfall deficits remained high across the state.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 5, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas began requiring that new power generators show proof of water access and rights
Description: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas began requiring that new power generators show proof of water access and rights before the council will add the power company to its state planning model.  The goal is to ensure that power companies use their water supplies sensibly to have adequate supplies during drought.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Feb. 6, 2013

Title: The Texas Farm Bureau reported that food prices have risen rapidly in the past three months
Description: The Texas Farm Bureau reported that food prices have risen rapidly in the past three months as food prices reflect the strain of the 2011 drought and the Midwest drought in 2012 on agriculture.  Thirteen of the 16 items it surveys every three months rose considerably, particularly meats.  The price of lean ground beef rose by 10.5 percent, while the cost of top cut sirloin steak climbed roughly 19 percent or nearly one dollar since the last survey three months ago.  KJ 97 KAJA-FM (San Antonio, Texas), March 27, 2013

Title: Mistletoe production down in Texas
Description: A mistletoe grower in Priddy in central Texas said that the dry conditions prevented mistletoe from growing, resulting in a mistletoe shortage in the state and country.  Mistletoe is a parasitic plant that grows on some trees.  Since drought has killed many trees across the state, mistletoe wasn’t faring so well either.  Q 101.9 KQXT-FM (Texas), Dec. 24, 2012

Title: Drought and high hay prices led to what some Humane Society officials in Texas term the “Donkey Crisis of 2012”
Description: Drought and high hay prices led to what some Humane Society officials in Texas term the “Donkey Crisis of 2012.”  Drought drastically reduced grass and hay production in 2011, leaving donkeys with little to eat and making the purchase of hay for feeding donkeys very costly.  An investigator with the Humane Society of North Texas said that a 60-pound bale of hay cost about $14, double what it cost two years ago.  The Humane Society and the Peaceful Valley Donkey Rescue (PVDR) have been overwhelmed with donkeys for the past year and a half and want to give them to good homes.  The PVDR has roughly 1,000 donkeys at its headquarters.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 25, 2012

Title: Texas scored a D-minus on an assessment of its drinking water
Description: Texas scored a D-minus on an assessment of its drinking water by the American Society of Civil Engineers.  The D-minus reflected the poor availability of drinking water in Texas after years of drought and did not indicate that the water was of inferior quality.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 8, 2012
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Hectic cattle sales in Texas
Description: About 36,000 cattle were sold at auction in Texas, nearly three times the 13,400 head sold just a couple of weeks ago and nearing the 43,600 head sold this time during the unforgiving 2011 drought, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.Kansas City Star & KansasCity.com (Mo.), July 24, 2012

Title: Tree mortality survey underway in Texas to assess drought damage
Description: The Texas Forestry Service is attempting to determine more accurately how many trees were killed by the recent intense drought.  Crews are counting the number of dead trees and noting insects and tree diseases within a 75-foot radius on seven hundred plots of land.  A previous tree mortality estimate by the Texas Forest Service put the number as high as 500 million.  The assessment is expected to take two months.  Another more thorough tree study is also planned.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), May 14, 2012

Title: Burn bans in Young, Stephens and Eastland counties in Texas
Description: Outdoor burn bans continue for Young, Stephens, and Eastland counties. The Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association estimates that it may take more than 5 years to rebuild the Texas cattle industry. To foster the proper rebuilding of herds and help maintain the cattle infrastructure, the Texas Agrilife Extension Service has hosted educational programs throughout the state. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Dalls/Fort Worth, Texas - April 26, 2012
Places: Texas, Eastland County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Burn bans, water use restrictions remain in place in southern Texas
Description: Burn bans remain in effect for La Salle, Webb, Jim Wells, McMullen, Live Oak, Bee, Kleberg, and Refugio counties. Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Residents of Victoria and Corpus Christi are also encouraged to conserve water. Additional locations that have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS), according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality: Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary) Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary) Calhoun County: Port Comfort (stage 1) Jim Wells County: Alice (stage 1), English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3), and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary) Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary) Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary) Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary) Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - April 19, 2012

Title: Producers waiting for moisture before planting in southern Texas
Description: In spite of improved rainfall, producers were still waiting on additional showers for planting crops. Although some soil moisture was available in many areas, it was not enough in general for planting. Cotton farmers over the Rolling Plains in particular were on edge with moisture badly needed before planting. Producers were pre-irrigating where irrigation was available. Winter wheat was mostly a loss because of drought conditions. Pasture and rangeland improved slightly while livestock were in fair to good condition with supplemental feeding. Many trees, shrubs, and grasses have died or responded poorly to the recent moisture. Some poorer fields over the Rolling Plains were being "disastered out" by crop insurance companies. Lubbock entered stage 2 of its drought contingency plan on April 1 because of an anticipated gap in water supply. Stage 2 restrictions limit water usage to certain times and certain days of the week, while refraining from certain other aesthetic or non-essential uses of water. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Lubbock, Texas - April 19, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought allowed new weed to thrive in parts of Texas
Description: An invasive weed of Mediterranean origin called bastard cabbage was thriving in parts of Texas where drought killed lots of grass, such as in overgrazed pastures, stated the director of vegetation management for the Texas Transportation Department.  Rapistrum rugosum grows to 2 to 5 feet in height and has full leafy branches with yellow flowers.  The weed was crowding out bluebonnets and other wildflowers in some areas and making it difficult for grass to reestablish itself.  Efforts were underway to control the weed.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 10, 2012

Title: Ninety-seven counties in Texas ban outdoor burning
Description: Ninety-seven counties in south and West Texas and the Panhandle have bans on outdoor burning due to dry conditions and elevated fire danger.  Odessa American (Texas), April 9, 2012

Title: Burn bans, water restrictions in effect in south Texas
Description: Burn bans remain in effect for La Salle, Webb, Jim Wells, McMullen, Live Oak, Bee, Kleberg, and Refugio counties. Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Residents of Corpus Christi are also encouraged to conserve water. Additional locations that have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS), according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality: Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary) Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary) Calhoun County: Port Comfort (stage 1) Jim Wells County: Alice (stage 1), English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3), and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary) Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary) Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary) Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary) Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) In the past year, a donkey rescue group collected almost 800 abandoned donkeys, animals that were abandoned because of the drought. Also, although conditions have improved after several weeks of rain, Coastal Bend livestock producers continued to supplemental feed their herds. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - April 5, 2012

Title: In Texas, water restrictions, burn bans continue; dry weather keeping migrating birds away
Description: Burn bans remain in effect for La Salle, Webb, Jim Wells, McMullen, Live Oak, Bee, Kleberg, and Refugio counties. Duval County recently removed its burn ban. Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Residents in Victoria and Corpus Christi are also strongly encouraged to conserve water. Additional locations that have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS), according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality: Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary) Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary) Calhoun County: Port Comfort (stage 1) Jim Wells County: Alice (stage 1), English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3), and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary) Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary) Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary) Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary) Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) According to an Associated Press article dated March 1, the Texas drought has affected the migration of many birds that normally come to Texas during the cool season but have gone elsewhere because of the lack of food. This includes whooping cranes, ducks, geese, and other waterfowl. The Lower Colorado River Authority (LCRA) announced that, for the first time ever, they will not be releasing water to support rice production. This will have a profound impact on rice production, as the production of Texas rice contributes more than $200 million to the state economy each year and accounts for thousands of jobs. The Texas Crop and Weather Reports for February 28 and March 6 noted that in the coastal bend district, livestock were still being supplemented with hay and protein. In the western areas (considered part of the south district), recent rainfall improved range and pastures, allowing livestock producers to cut back on supplemental feeding. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - March 8, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: Drought caused birds that usually winter in the Texas Panhandle to go elsewhere
Description: Drought caused birds that usually winter in the Texas Panhandle to rethink their plans.  Just 15,000 ducks were in the Panhandle this winter, in comparison with 36,000 last winter.  Fewer ponds and reduced surface water supplies probably discouraged the ducks from staying there.  Instead, more ducks were wintering in the state’s prairie areas, where biologists estimate there were 1.2 million ducks, up from 885,000 last year.  Biologists wonder how the usual winter habitation might affect the birds’ well being as they begin the return journey to their summer habitat and attempt to reproduce.  The Daily News (Texas), March 1, 2012

Title: Two Texas congressmen objected to the Air Force’s plans to move eight C-130 Hercules aircraft from Fort Worth, Texas
Description: Two Texas congressmen objected to the Air Force’s plans to move eight C-130 Hercules aircraft from Fort Worth to Montana, fearing that Texas may be less prepared to fight wildfires in the upcoming fire season.  The assignment of the aircraft to the Texas Air National Guard makes them accessible to the state in the event of disasters, such as a wildfire or a hurricane.   Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Feb. 28, 2012

Title: Forage still inadequate, water restrictions in place across north Texas
Description: Despite the improvement in north Texas, only 18 percent of pasture and rangeland across the state was rated as good or excellent. Forage was still inadequate in many areas. Supplemental feeding, much of which is accomplished with out-of-state hay, remains widespread across the state. Water restrictions remain in place across north Texas. Tarrant Regional Water District (87 percent capacity) and Dallas Water (89 percent) are in stage 1, while the North Texas Municipal Water District will remain in stage 3 until June 1. For Groesbeck (Limestone County), only voluntary conservation is currently ongoing. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Dallas/Fort Worth, Texas - February 25, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Burn bans, water use restrictions remain in effect in Texas
Description: Burn bans remain in effect for La Salle, Webb, Duval, Jim Wells, McMullen, Live Oak, Bee, Kleberg, and Refugio counties. Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Residents in Victoria are also strongly encouraged to conserve water. Corpus Christi residents are encouraged to voluntarily conserve water. More stringent water restrictions were considered over the past few months, but some local officials were concerned that water restrictions would curtail revenue generated by water usage by companies and residences (and the only way to keep the revenue up during restrictions was to raise water use rates). Additional locations that have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS), according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality: Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary) Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary) Calhoun County: Port Comfort (stage 1) Jim Wells County: Alice (stage 1), English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3), and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary) Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary) Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary) Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary) Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) The Texas Forecast Service recently reported that the Texas drought killed an estimated 5.6 million trees. The Lower Colorado River Authority is expected to announce on March 1 that they will likely not release irrigation water for thousands of farmers in rice growing regions. If true, this will not only impact the rice farmers, but ranchers as well (however, most ranchers have already culled their herds). Also, it is suspected that the whooping crane population may be more widely dispersed this year because of the drought, because of the lack of their important food source - blue crabs. The Texas Crop and Weather Reports for February 14 and 21 contained the following information: In the Coastal Bend district, livestock producers were still supplementing cattle with hay and protein, in part due to lack of forage. For the western areas (considered part of the south district), supplemental feed for cattle was still greatly needed as many ranchers’ hay stocks were short, and prices continued to rise. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - February 23, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: Live oak trees in Texas sloughing off bark
Description: Live oak trees have been sloughing off bark in many parts of Texas, according to an Abilene area arborist, who stated that the bark was coming loose on the lower trunk, sometimes in small patches and, in other instances, in much larger sections.  The bark was coming loose because the cambium beneath the bark, which transports of nutrients for the tree, had died.  Other arborists across the state confirmed that they were seeing the same problem among live oak trees.  The problem is assumed to be drought-related.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Feb. 7, 2012

Title: Volunteer fire departments across Texas gearing up for another harsh wildfire season
Description: Volunteer fire departments across Texas were gearing up for another harsh wildfire season since drought was projected to persist for the state.  Unfortunately, state budget cuts eliminated millions of dollars’ worth of grants for volunteer fire departments, making the task of keeping communities safe an enormous challenge and one for which some departments feel unprepared.  A firefighter in Angelina County stated that his two tanker trucks were 25 and 30 years old and were both homemade.  The ages of the vehicles worries him and leaves him wondering if the vehicle is safe and can perform when needed.  A member of the Huntington VFD also expressed concern about the lack of appropriate equipment.  KTRE-TV ABC 9 (Lufkin, Texas), Jan. 18, 2012

Title: Burn bans, water restrictions continue to affect south Texas
Description: Fire danger is currently moderate to high because of gusty winds and the recent lack of rainfall. As of January 12, burn bans were in effect for 14 counties in south central Texas. The counties with established outdoor burn bans include Bexar, Dewitt, Dimmit, Edwards, Frio, Karnes, Kerr, Kinney, Maverick, Medina, Real, Uvalde, Val Verde, and Zavala counties. Currently, Atascosa, Bandera, Bastrop, Blanco, Burnet, Caldwell, Comal, Fayette, Gillespie, Gonzales, Gudalupe, Hays, Kendall, Lavaca, Lee, Llano, Travis, Williamson, and Wilson counties have lifted their burn bans. Residents in all counties should contact their local county judge’s office or fire marshal before deciding to conduct any type of outdoor burning. The Texas Crop and Weather Report issued by Texas A&M indicated moisture from recent rains was already drying up. Earlier green-up turned brown with freezing temperatures and lack of continued rainfall. With little or no standing crop of native grasses, livestock producers continued to provide heavy supplemental feed for cattle. Some larger ranches sold off more cattle because of projections of continued drought. The San Antonio Water System (SAWS) is currently back in stage 1 water restrictions. The mandatory restrictions and the more frequent rain events have helped to keep the Edwards Aquifer level from falling below 650 feet. The Edwards Aquifer is currently reading 652.4 feet (as of January 12). This is 17.6 feet below the historical monthly average for January, which is 670.0 feet. The aquifer level is 26.8 feet below the level observed on this date in January 2011. Once new restrictions are in place, they will remain in place for 30 days after rising above the trigger level. After 30 days, if the aquifer level remains above the trigger level, then restrictions will be updated. Many communities across south central Texas have implemented the first, second, third, and fourth stages of water restrictions because of the long-term dry conditions and decreasing water supplies. The Barton Springs remain in critical stage 3 with a ten-day average flow of 22.2 cubic feet per minute. The flow rates remain very low despite above-average rainfall in December 2010. The rains did provide some recharge, but the benefits will be temporary unless significant rainfall is observed over the next 6 months. Austin remains in stage 2 water restrictions, San Marcos is in stage 1 water restrictions and the city of Kerrville remains in stage 4 water restrictions. Locations that do not currently have mandatory restrictions continue to strongly promote year round water conservation. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Austin/San Antonio, Texas - January 12, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Discussion of drought's effect on power generation in Texas
Description: The continuing drought in Texas and the threat of insufficient water supplies to produce adequate power had Texas Senate Democrats nervous about the state’s ability to avoid brownouts and to continue to draw businesses to the state.  The topic was discussed at a Senate Committee on Business and Commerce meeting.  State utility authorities asserted that electricity was too cheaply produced to offer any incentive to upgrade infrastructure and encourage more efficient means of generating electricity to avoid drought-induced brownouts.  One senator expressed concern that the state’s power grid deterred companies from setting up shop in Texas.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Jan. 10, 2012

Title: Last year's drought led Texas pecan trees to produce excessive number of nuts
Description: Drought during the early part of the growing season led pecan trees to produce an abundance of nuts, according to an AgriLife Extension horticulture specialist in College Station, resulting in an anticipated harvest of 65 million pounds of pecans this year.  Last year’s drought badly stressed the trees, prompting them to produce more nuts than usual to ensure the survival of the species, which led to branch breakage, due to the excessive numbers of nuts.  The Vindicaor (Liberty, Texas), Oct. 12, 2012

Title: Drought caused $974,548,606 in agricultural losses in Texas in 2012
Description: Drought caused $974,548,606 in agricultural losses in Texas in 2012, according to data from the Natural Resources Defense Council, and ranked 10th for the most crop losses from drought.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Sept. 1, 2013

Title: Texas drought led to mistletoe shortage
Description: A florist shop in Excelsior did not carry mistletoe this year because drought in Texas reduced the crop and lowered the quality of the mistletoe.  Two local rotary clubs had to make alternate plans for their mistletoe sale to raise money for a food bank.  Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune (Minn.), Dec. 13, 2011

Title: Texas Parks and Wildlife Department aiming to raise $4.6 million through donations from public in effort to keep parks open
Description: The Texas Parks and Wildlife Department was aiming to raise $4.6 million through donations from the public in an effort to keep parks open, according to a series of news conferences held on December 6.  The parks service hoped to make up $3 million in lost visitation and $1.6 million in projected revenue from donations offered while renewing vehicle registrations. Since park visitations have been down due to drought and heat, the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department received roughly $1.2 million less in entrance and use fees in the 2011 fiscal year compared to the previous year, while revenue was already $2 million below projected levels for this fiscal year.  The state parks system gets half of its annual $69 million needed to cover operating expenses from the state and half from visitors fees.  Amarillo Globe News (Texas), Dec. 6, 2011

Title: Thousands of horses and donkeys abandoned across Texas
Description: Thousands of horses and donkeys continue to be abandoned across Texas as the scarcity and high cost of hay has made it difficult to care for the animals, according to a horse specialist with Texas A&M University.  Drought has driven hay and feed prices to new highs and dried up pastures, leaving many animal owners to try to sell, but there just isn’t a market for horses or donkeys.  Since many ranchers have sold livestock, even fewer horses are needed to ride to check on the cattle.  Texas ranchers have been able to purchase hay from Oregon and Idaho, but supplies were dwindling there, too.  Allentown Morning Call (Pa.), Dec. 3, 2011

Title: Long-term drought still affecting water supplies in Texas
Description: Precipitation in December only managed to put a dent in the ongoing drought for the entire state even though most cities received above normal precipitation for the month. ... Water supply levels continued to decrease and values were exceptionally low in the High Plains and Trans Pecos regions, according to the Texas Water Development Board. Overall there are 999 public water systems that are asking their customers to restrict water use, compared to 1,004 a month ago. Of these systems, 646 are asking customers to follow a mandatory watering schedule and 353 are asking customers to follow a voluntary watering schedule. There are 51 public water systems that have restricted all outside watering, compared to 53 a month ago. The availability of unappropriated water for new water use permits continues to decrease in all river basins in the State, and the search for long-term, dependable alternate sources of water remains a high priority issue.Texas Statewide Drought Situation Report, Jan. 18, 2012

Title: Texas barbeque restaurant owner faced with rising beef prices
Description: Barbeque restaurant owners are faced with rising beef prices and are considering price increases on their menus.  One restaurant owner in Lockhart stated that briskets cost several dollars more than they did at this time last year.  KEYE-TV We are Austin.com (Texas), Nov. 16, 2011

Title: Blue Bell Creameries in Brenham, Texas made less butter pecan ice cream because drought reduced pecan production in Texas
Description: Blue Bell Creameries made less butter pecan ice cream because drought reduced pecan production in Texas and drove up prices for the nuts, according to the company spokesman.  The business did not want to compromise quality by using fewer nuts or smaller pieces.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 16, 2012

Title: Fed cattle prices rose to a new high of $127 per hundredweight
Description: Fed cattle prices rose to a new high of $127 per hundredweight, according to a livestock economist with the Texas AgriLife Extension.  Two months ago, fed cattle sold for $113 per hundredweight.  One year ago, fed cattle sold for $98 per hundredweight.  Drought was one of several factors driving the price to record levels as producers sold many livestock early due to shortages of grazing, water and hay.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 15, 2011

Title: Better Business Bureaus in Texas receiving up to 75 percent more calls about foundation repairs
Description: Better Business Bureaus in Texas were receiving up to 75 percent more calls about foundation repairs than last year.  The bureau has since included cracking foundations to a number of problems that arise from drought.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Nov. 7, 2011

Title: Remaining cotton stalks a problem for Texas farmers
Description: Cotton did not grow well in many parts of Texas due to drought, which, in turn, was making it a challenge to grow follow-up crops because cotton stalks remained, particularly in east, central and south Texas.  The state cotton specialist stated that many farmers were having trouble with cotton stalks that were not easily controlled with tillage or herbicides, which are less effective during drought.  In some areas, such as Taylor and Jones counties, the dryland cotton did not germinate without moisture, so stalks were not a problem there.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Nov. 6, 2011

Title: Texas Drought Survival Kit
Description: The Texas Parks and Wildlife Department created a Drought Survival Kit with a multitude of tips to teach people how to help wildlife, manage their yards and lower their water bills during drought.  Dallas Morning News (Texas), Nov. 5, 2011

Title: Planned power plants in Texas opposed over water supply concerns
Description: Energy projects across Texas were struggling to find water supplies and were finding themselves at odds with Texans over the water needed to operate the plants.  Groups concerned about the water supply were pushing government agencies to deny construction permits to potential power plants and were litigating to keep power plants out of some communities deemed to be short of water.  A study done by the University of Texas showed that 287 million gallons of water will be needed in 2020 to meet Texas’ electricity demand, which was roughly 100 billion gallons more than was needed in 2000, but the water demand already exceeds supply, according to a water expert who previously worked with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.  There were nine coal-fired plants in the works across the state with 19 already in operation.  A power plant planned for Bay City lost support despite opting to install a cooling system that uses less water.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 2, 2011
Categories: Business & Industry, Energy, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Monarch butterflies scarce in Texas during fall migration
Description: Monarch butterflies were scarce in Texas this year when they should be flitting across the state on their annual fall migration to Mexico.  One invertebrate biologist with the Texas Parks & Wildlife Department in Austin reported seeing just four or so monarchs in the past three weeks.  It was thought that the reduction in flowers that provide nectar for the butterflies and many acres burned by wildfires resulted in a wide migration route, which could explain why monarchs were seen from the Davis Mountains in West Texas to the I-35 corridor, although they would normally fly a narrower route.  An entomologist who coordinates the Texas Monarch Watch, stemming from the monarch education and research organization in Kansas, was concerned about the number of dead plants, few butterflies and dying juniper in the Hill Country and noted that there was precious little to nourish the butterflies on their journey.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 2, 2011

Title: One-fifth of Texas water systems have restrictions on water use
Description: There were 956 public water systems with voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in Texas, according to a commissioner with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality who presented the status of Texas’ water systems to the Senate Natural Resources Committee.  Fifty-five systems did not allow any outdoor watering, while 23 water systems were so low that it was unclear how much water they had or had less than a six month supply.  Of the 175 major water supply reservoirs in the state, 109 contained less than 60 percent of capacity by late September.  The reservoirs have a combined capacity of 31.1 million acre feet, but hold only 18.8 million acre feet.  Water rights have been cut back in 1,005 instances, as those with senior water rights get priority over those with more recent water rights.  There are 4,721 community water systems in Texas.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 1, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: More than 4,000 people petitioned for use of National Guard, other Texas resources to transport hay
Description: Roughly 4,400 signatures were gathered to petition the governor of Texas to utilize the National Guard or other state resources to help transport hay to Texas livestock.  The chief executive of a nonprofit farm-animal rescue agency in Argyle started the petition.  The rising number of abandoned horses and donkeys across the state underscored the difficulty and expense of locating hay.  The New York Times, Oct. 31, 2011

Title: Alabama cattleman purchased at least 1,600 head of cattle in Texas
Description: A livestock auction owner from Uniontown purchased at least 1,600 cows at cattle sales in drought-stricken Texas to bring back to Alabama.  The cost for each animal ranged from $650 to $1,200, which were very good prices.  Montgomery Advertiser (Ala.), Oct. 23, 2011

Title: Persistent drought continued to take its toll on Texas wildlife
Description: The persistent drought continued to take its toll on Texas wildlife as revealed in statewide wildlife surveys performed by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department.  No new fawns were found among 76 white-tailed deer in a 30-mile area in the Panhandle.  In the same area, only 3 quail were seen, where biologists would normally find 15.  Deer were dying from inadequate water supplies in South Texas, where 20 dead adult deer were found on one ranch.  Quail were not able to reproduce this year, according to the game bird program leader for Texas Parks and Wildlife.  In the northeastern Panhandle and north central Texas, the quail population was at historic lows, with a count of just 5 in areas where 21 were usually found.  Only one quail was found in a 20-mile radius in the Hill Country where 5 or more were normally found.  Six scaled quail were seen in the Trans Pecos region of West Texas where usually 16 or more birds would be found.  The antelope population in the Trans Pecos area has been suffering from a parasite for several years that has reduced the number of antelope.  Drought will likely further reduce antelope numbers.  A survey of antelopes in the northeastern Panhandle in June and July revealed 16 fawns among the 100 does, whereas there would usually be 35 fawns, indicating a fairly high mortality rate.  Antelope, deer and mule deer bucks may not fare well this breeding season because they use lots of energy and require adequate food to recover well afterward. Does were already doing poorly, which explains the meager fawn crops, which was as low as 27 percent in parts of the Southeast and Central Texas.  Ash juniper, which is drought-tolerant, was dying in the Hill Country.  The Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 13, 2011

Title: Texas bats altering behavior during drought
Description: Drought has reduced the food availability for bats in Texas, forcing them to emerge earlier in the evenings to search for food, which puts the bats in greater danger from predators, such as hawks, falcons, raccoons, owls and snakes.  More infant bats than usual were dying, suggesting that adult bats were not able to find enough food to supply themselves and their young.  The 20 million bats from the Bracken cave were coming out up to two hours before nightfall to travel greater distances to reach insects that inhabit corn and cotton plants.  The bats in Austin were emerging early, as well.  The 3 million bats in the Old Tunnel Wildlife Management Area near Fredericksburg normally take 40 to 60 minutes to fly out of the abandoned train tunnel, but presently take just six to 10 minutes to come out for the night.  The manager of the Old Tunnel Wildlife Management Area noted that the number of bats usually doubles in August as the young bats begin to fly, but the drastic change in the evening departures from the tunnel indicates that there are many fewer bats, meaning that many young probably did not survive.  The Houston urban biologist for the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department shared that she has noticed more dead baby bats on the ground and assumes that the adults don’t have enough to adequately feed their young.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Oct. 4, 2011
Places: Texas, Bracken, TX, Fredericksburg, TX, Houston, TX, Austin, TX

Title: Additional air tankers arrived in Austin to fight fires across Texas
Description: Two Canadian air tankers arrived in Austin from Saskatchewan on September 28 to support firefighting efforts across the state.  The airplanes came from Canada because there were not enough heavy air tankers in the U.S. to meet demand.  The Texas Forest Service fought 86 fires that scorched 4,698 acres in the past week.  12 News KBMT (Beaumont, Texas), Sept. 29, 2011

Title: Food, water sparse for monarch butterflies migrating through Texas
Description: Monarch butterflies congregated along the Llano River and supped on the nectar from Frostweed, Water Hemlock, Swamp Milkweed, Goldenrod and Purple Mistflower since drought eliminated the usual fall flowers.  The journey across Texas is anticipated to be very challenging for the butterflies since food and water is difficult to find.  Less food will lower the butterflies’ fat reserves and jeopardize their survival this winter in Mexico.  The founder of Monarch Watch encouraged Texans to put out feeders containing Gatorade or Juicy Juice, small dishes of applesauce or slices of watermelon at flower level in their gardens to provide some sustenance for the butterflies as they travel south.  San Antonio Express-News (Texas), Sept. 29, 2011
Places: Texas, Kimble County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX

Title: Texas ranchers downsizing during drought, according to survey
Description: The Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association surveyed 8,995 ranchers and found that of the 872 respondents, 8 percent of them anticipated having no cattle in 2012, but intended to rebuild their herds in the future.  Sixteen percent of ranchers have not altered their herd sizes in response to drought, while 84 percent have culled some cattle compared to their three year average.  On average, ranchers downsized their herds by 38 percent.  The online survey was done in late August.  Nationwide, the cattle herd was the smallest it has been since the 1950s.  Lufkin News (Texas), Sept. 20, 2011

Title: Wildfires blaze in Bastrop County and throughout Texas
Description: A wind-driven wildfire that began September 4 burned 30,000 acres and nearly 600 homes in Bastrop County.  More than 5,000 people fled their homes.  Dozens of fires blazed in Texas on September 4 as strong winds from Tropical Storm Lee drove the fires across a parched landscape.  Odessa American (Texas), Sept. 6, 2011.  The Bastrop County fire ultimately burned more than 34,000 acres, ended two lives and destroyed 1,600 homes.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 15 and 26, 2011
Places: Texas, Bastrop County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Cass County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Harris County, TX, Harrison County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Leon County, TX, Limestone County, TX, Montague County, TX, Montgomery County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Rusk County, TX, Travis County, TX, Waller County, TX

Title: Water restrictions imposed in 856 Texas communities
Description: As of Sept. 1, 2011, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality reported there were 295 systems (190 ground water, 143 surface water) with voluntary restrictions in place, and 561 systems (442 ground water and 271 surface water) with mandatory restrictions in place. The total number of systems affected was 856, out of the 4,717 active community water systems in the state.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Ranchers sent 145,000 Texas cattle to better pasture in September 2011
Description: There were 140 percent more breeding cows or 145,000 head transported out of Texas to greener pastures in September 2011, compared with 2010, according to the Texas Animal Health Commission. An economist with the Texas AgriLife Extension Service estimated that by January 2012, roughly 12 percent of the state’s 5 million cattle will have been shipped, slaughtered or sold, dramatically reducing the number of cattle in Texas.  The Macon Telegraph (Ga.), Oct. 11, 2011

Title: Drought beneficial for reducing mosquito-borne illnesses in Texas
Description: Drought has diminished the mosquito population because there were fewer water sources for them to breed, noted the Nacogdoches Natural Resources Conservation District Conservationist.  As a result, there were fewer cases of mosquito-borne illnesses, such as encephalitis and West Nile virus, among humans or livestock.  Fewer mosquitoes can be beneficial to those who organize large outdoor events because they would not need the evaluation or services of an exterminator.  Drought can also present an opportune time to remove silt from stock ponds to allow more room for water when the rains do return.  KTRE (Lufkin, Texas), Aug. 31, 2011

Title: Texas drought affects revenue for water utilities
Description: Drought has impacted the revenue of many water utilities across the state as outdoor irrigation increases, boosting revenue, or stringent water restrictions cut into water use and lead to a decrease in revenue.  San Marcos, San Antonio, Odessa and Lubbock were enjoying higher than usual revenues.  Robert Lee, on the other hand, was experiencing an income drop of 40 percent since severe water restrictions were in effect because its reservoir was nearly dry.  Llano, too, had a 10 percent decline in revenue.  Soil dries and shifts during drought, spurring an increased number of water main breaks as has been seen in Houston and Austin.  These repairs can be expensive, costing up to $350 per foot to replace the line, according to the director of the Austin Water Utility.  Some communities were seeking new expensive water supplies.  The Colorado River Municipal Water District was constructing a pipeline at a cost of $142 million, while Amarillo spent more than $100 million to purchase groundwater.  KEYE-TV (Texas), Aug 30, 2011

Title: Fewer flowers across Texas to nourish migrating hummingbirds
Description: There were fewer flowers across Texas to offer nourishment to migrating hummingbirds, prompting hummingbird aficionados to put out feeders to help the birds on their journey.  The drought threatens 18 species of hummingbirds as they fly through Texas on their way to Central America.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Aug. 28, 2011

Title: Montana hay grower transporting hay to Texas
Description: A hay grower in Fromberg received about six telephone calls daily from Texas ranchers wanting hay since he had placed advertisements in Texas offering hay for sale.  The Montana man has three weeks’ worth of orders for hay to deliver to ranchers 1,400 miles away.  Billing Gazette (Mont.), Aug. 23, 2011

Title: 796 Texas communities have restrictions on water use
Description: There were 796 communities in Texas with restrictions on water use, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.  Of those, 506 had mandatory restrictions on water use.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 22, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas arranged for backup power supplies
Description: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas asked two electricity providers to reactivate two natural gas units each to make sure that the state has sufficient electricity and can avoid more rotating power outages.  NRG Energy and Garland Power and Light are prepared to provide a total of 400 megawatts if and when needed through October 2011.  There is concern that there may be inadequate supplies of cooling water for power plants if drought and heat persist.  These reactivated units will only be used to prevent power outages and will not be used when there is an adequate power supply.  Pearland Journal (Texas), Aug. 16, 2011
Places: Texas, Denton County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Jack County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Parker County, TX, Tarrant County, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: Texas 2011 cotton losses estimated at $2.2 billion
Description: Estimated 2011 Cotton Losses for Texas 2011 TX Planted Acreage: 7.12 million acres. 2011 TX Est. Harvest Acreage: 3.40 million acres. 2011 Est. TX Yield: 635 pounds per acre. 2011 Est. TX Abandonment: 52 percent. 2011 Est. TX Production: 4.50 million 480-lb bales (2.16 billion lbs). 2011 Est. TX Cotton Value: approx. $1.8 billion (using last year’s price.) Contrast with 2010: 2010 TX Planted Acreage: 5.57 million acres. 2010 TX Harvested Acreage: 5.35 million acres. 2010 TX Yield: 703 pounds per acre. 2010 TX Abandonment: 4 percent. 2010 TX Production: 7.84 million 480-lb bales (3.76 billion lbs). 2010 TX Cotton Value: approx. $3.1 billion ($0.83 per pound). Comments: The estimated Texas cotton value for 2011 is estimated using the 2010 U.S. cotton price of 83 cents per bushel. Cotton prices have been running higher this year but have fallen in recent weeks. Early in the year, cotton was trading near $2 per pound, but in recent weeks the price has fallen to near $1. If Texas had experienced a near-optimum year in 2011 (see 2010 for near-optimum results), the state could have achieved a production total of approximately 4.80 billion pounds (1.00 billion 480-pound bales). This is a rounded value assuming a 2011 optimum harvested acreage of 6.85 million acres (4 percent abandonment) and an optimum yield of 700 pounds per acre. At the 2010 U.S. cotton price of 83 cents per pound, this year’s Texas crop had a potential value of $4.0 billion. Given the 2011 estimated Texas cotton value of approximately $1.8 billion, it is fairly safe to say that the raw losses from this year’s cotton crop are in the ballpark of $2.2 billion. As an aside, the record-high cotton abandonment in Texas was set in 1998, with 42%. -Brad Rippey, USDA

Title: Drought could be having long-term impact on Texas wildlife
Description: The record-breaking drought in 2011 is endangering entire ecosystems across Texas. According to news reports, of the state's 3,700 streams, 15 major rivers and more than 200 reservoirs at least seven reservoirs are effectively empty and more than half of the streams and rivers are at below normal flow rates. Fish are among the first species to suffer, but the lack of water also affects plants, insects and other animals, including migratory birds, bats, song birds, antelope, deer, and predators. From the Associated Press, published by many media outlets in early August.

Title: Hot, dry conditions discouraged park visitations and overnight stays in Texas parks
Description: Hot, dry conditions discouraged park visitations and overnight stays in Texas parks.  Bans on outdoor burning and using charcoal grills also made park stays less enjoyable.  Parks that offered water-based recreation noticed the greatest reduction in visitation.  In August, visits to Garner State Park on the Frio River and Pedernales Falls State Park on the Pedernales River were down by nearly 40 percent, while visits to the Guadalupe River State Park were down by 60 percent, compared to the same time in 2010.  About 50 Texas parks saw revenue fall by at least 20 percent, while overall revenue to Texas parks dropped by 24 percent in August.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Nov. 21, 2011
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Record numbers of donkeys abandoned across Texas
Description: More than 300 donkeys were rescued in Texas as owners, who cannot afford to provide hay and water during drought, continue to  abandon the animals in record numbers.  Texas is overpopulated with donkeys because they are worth little and cannot be sold at most auctions, leaving owners few options to get rid of them when they no longer want the donkeys.  KATV-TV ABC 7 Little Rock (AR), July 28, 2011 and Allentown Morning Call (Pa.),  Dec. 3, 2011

Title: Sparse hay supply led to increased cost in Texas
Description: Ranchers purchasing hay must hand over at least $100 per grass roll, whereas they used to cost $40.  Drought has browned pastures, stunted hay growth and forced ranchers to feed hay. KTBC-TV MyFoxAustin (Texas), July 25, 2011

Title: Food prices rose slightly, due to drought
Description: Food prices rose slightly, due to drought, according to recent government and industry surveys.  The USDA estimated that grocery bills will cost 4 percent more in 2011 than in 2010.  KTBC-TV MyFoxAustin (Texas), July 25, 2011

Title: Declining aquifer levels across Texas posing problems
Description: Homeowners relying on private wells in Texas were discovering that the water table has fallen, leaving them with no water until pumps were lowered or wells were drilled deeper.  Drought has meant that aquifers weren’t recharging while demand has increased due to drought and population growth.  The greatest depletion of groundwater appeared to be occurring along Interstate 35 near Fort Worth, Austin and San Antonio.  Aquifer levels declined by 20 to 50 feet in parts of the Upper Trinity Groundwater Conservation District, according to the district president.  The Blanco-Pedernales Groundwater Conservation District has experienced even greater declines in some areas.  The Blanco and Pedernales rivers no longer flow.  San Angelo area wells in the Lipan-Kickapoo Water Conservation District were reaching record lows, according to the general manager.  Well users were required to cut their water use by 40 percent.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), July 24, 2011

Title: Drought may be responsible for an increase in the number of rabies cases in Texas
Description: Drought may be responsible for an increase in the number of rabies cases in Texas, particularly in the northern part of the state, say veterinarians and state health officials.  Depleted water sources could be leading wild animals to approach residential areas for food and water, bringing the animals into contact with domestic pets.  There were 591 rabies cases, according to preliminary state records.  Last year, there were 387 statewide for the same time period.  In Denton, Johnson, Parker, Tarrant and Wise counties, there were 51 rabies cases through the end of June, compared with 25 cases in the first six months of 2010.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (TX), July 23, 2011

Title: Burn bans in effect in 247 Texas counties
Description: There were 247 counties in Texas with bans on outdoor burning, according to the Texas Forest Service, as drought hangs on and raises the fire danger.  The previous record for the greatest number of Texas counties with burn bans occurred in January 2006 when 221 counties prohibited outdoor burning.  KVUE-TV ABC Austin (Texas), July 18, 2011

Title: Ragweed season in Central Texas ought to be milder than usual this year
Description: The ragweed plant population was halved by the drought, according to an Austin allergist.  As a result, the ragweed season should not be as uncomfortable for Central Texas allergy sufferers this year.  KVUE (Texas), July 18, 2011

Title: Certain restrictions and permitting requirements lifted to ease hay transport in Texas
Description: The Texas Agriculture Commissioner requested and received a waiver that lifts some restrictions and permitting requirements to hasten the hay transportation for ranchers who desperately need it to sustain their livestock.  The waiver expires on August 4, but may be renewed if the governor extends the state’s disaster proclamation.  North Texas e-News, July 17, 2011 and The New York Times, Oct. 31, 2011

Title: A new electric usage record was set for July when Texas used 64,226 megawatts on July 14
Description: A new electric usage record was set for July when Texas used 64,226 megawatts on July 14, according to the spokeswoman for the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT).  The previous high usage for July was 63,400 megawatts, but that record has been topped three times this summer.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), July 21, 2011

Title: Reports of Texas cattle dying from water intoxication
Description: Cattle in various parts of Texas died from water intoxication after thunderstorms dropped rainfall over the drought-stricken state on July 12.  Many cattle hadn’t had adequate supplies and overindulged when they got the opportunity.  Odessa American (Texas), July 13, 2011

Title: Texas drought emergency extended
Description: Gov. Rick Perry extended the drought emergency for Texas as the ongoing drought continued to threaten water supplies, public health, property and the economy.  Dallas County was among the more than 50 counties included in the proclamation.  WBAP-AM 820 Arlington (Texas), June 9, 2014Texas Governor Rick Perry extended the drought emergency for more than 200 counties across the state.  The declaration authorizes needed measures to guard public health, property and the economy in drought-stricken parts of Texas.  KHOU-TV CBS 11 Houston (Texas), June 19, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Burn bans nearly statewide in Texas in summer 2011
Description: All but 26 of Texas' 254 counties had burn bans in place as of June 23, 2011.Austin-American Statesman, June 23, 2011

Title: Texas counties banning fireworks because of drought
Description: Almost 130 Texas counties had banned fireworks by late June, 2011, because of the drought.Fort Worth Star-Telegram, June 22, 2011

Title: Southeast Texas faces wildfire
Description: Wildfire in Grimes County, Texas had burned almost 5,300 acres and more than 70 homes and other buildings. Fire in Trinity and Polk counties had burned more than 20,222 acres and two homes. The Texas Forest Service was battling 17 large fires across 145,000 acres. A total of about 2,000 residents had been evacuated.  Austin-American Statesman, June 23, 2011
Places: Texas, Grimes County, TX, Houston, TX, Jasper County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Polk County, TX, Potter County, TX, Trinity County, TX, Walker County, TX, Waller County, TX

Title: Texas agriculture assessment shows drought's effects statewide
Description: AgriLife Extension reports show that a variety of crops and livestock across the entire state of Texas are affected by drought and heat.

Title: Texas statewide fire disaster proclamation extended
Description: The governor of Texas extended his statewide disaster proclamation and again sought help from the federal government for firefighting costs.  Wildfires have burned more than 460 homes and charred more than 2.8 million acres in Texas since November 2010.  The governor requested a federal disaster declaration in April, but was denied since the state had already received dozens of grants to cover some of the firefighting costs.  New York Times (N.Y.), June 11, 2011

Title: Texas had burn bans in 193 of its 254 counties
Description: Burn bans were in effect in 193 of Texas’ 254 counties as the drought persisted.  Officials were referring to the drought as “one of the worst in the past 100 years.”  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), June 7, 2011

Title: 175 water suppliers with voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in effect in Texas
Description: There were 175 water suppliers with voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in effect in Texas with many of them concentrated in the San Antonio area.  Statewide Texas has more than 4,500 water suppliers.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), June 5, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Texas cattle sales exceptionally high in June 2011
Description: Cattle sales in June rose to 482,450 head, which was the highest monthly sales figure since 2007, according to the Texas Department of Agriculture.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 11, 2011

Title: Texas' energy usage in June was 5 percent above that used in 2010
Description: Texas' energy usage in June was 5 percent above that used in 2010, according to the spokeswoman for the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT).  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), July 21, 2011

Title: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas recommended inspection of electrical lines and equipment
Description: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas recommended that all electric transmission and distribution companies inspect and clean their equipment to avoid more power outages like those that affected refineries in Texas City and in Galveston Island.  Dust, pollen, salt and other substances can build up when there is no precipitation to remove the materials.  When fog or mist moistens the layer of dust and debris, short-circuits sometimes occur, causing power outages.  Coastal areas and West Texas were thought to be more susceptible to this issue than other parts of the state.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 29, 2011

Title: The governor of Texas declared Days of Prayer for Rain
Description: The governor of Texas declared April 22 through April 24 to be Days of Prayer for Rain as the state endured intense drought and widespread wildfires.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 21, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Many resources used across Texas to fight wildfires
Description: The spate of wildfires across Texas brought 925 federal workers and 123 trucks, bulldozers and airplanes to assist with firefighting efforts mainly in West and North Texas, where almost 600 federal employees and 219 pieces of equipment were in use.  The U.S. Forest Service provided 717 people, while the Bureau of Land Management offered 74 people and 17 pieces of equipment to fight fires.  There were 21 major fires affecting at least 770,000 acres on April 18, as reported by the National Interagency Fire Center report.  there were 283 people from the Texas Forest Service and 90 pieces of equipment engaged in fighting fires on April 18, while private citizens offered the use 135 pieces of equipment and another 34 citizens volunteered to fight fires.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 18, 2011

Title: Wildfires led Texas governor to request major disaster declaration
Description: The governor of Texas requested a major disaster declaration for the state of Texas since wildfires have ravaged or endangered 252 of the state’s 254 counties.  In a letter to the president, the governor noted that at least 7,800 fires had scorched in excess of 1.5 million acres or 2,400 square miles and destroyed 244 homes while jeopardizing 8,500 more homes.  The declaration would provide funds to help the state fight the fires and deal with the aftermath.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 17, 2011

Title: More than 76 percent of Texas counties with burn bans
Description: There were 194 counties out of Texas’ 254 counties with burn bans in effect because drought and windy conditions raised the fire danger.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 13, 2011

Title: Surface water rights holders in Texas notified of possible restrictions
Description: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality sent letters to holders of surface water rights in the state to alert them to potential restrictions on their water rights if drought worsens.  Water rights holders in south central Texas and along the Concho River received notices of the possible restrictions in March.  Nearly all of the state was experiencing some degree of drought.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 11, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: More than 700,000 acres burned in Texas during last seven days
Description: More than 700,000 acres burned in Texas wildfires during the last seven days.  Odessa American (Texas), April 17, 2011

Title: Nearly 700 square miles of Texas burned in 81 wildfires between April 7 and April 13
Description: The Texas Forest Service reported that 81 fires during the last 7 days burned nearly 700 square miles.  These blazes were fought by more than 900 firefighters from Texas and 33 additional states.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 13, 2011

Title: More than 1 million acres burned in Texas since April 6
Description: More than 1 million acres burned in Texas since April 6, according to the Texas Forest Service.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 19, 2011

Title: The Texas Forest Service fought 15 fires on April 2
Description: The Texas Forest Service fought 15 wildfires that burned 2,359 acres across the state on April 2, prompting the evacuation of approximately 350 homes and 400 recreational vehicles.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 3, 2011.

Title: Wildfires burn more than 10,000 acres in Texas
